captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Monday, January 3rd,
2011. Happy four year Youtube-versary! I dressed
up cause, you know, it's our special day.

So Hank, in today's video I though I would
answer some of Google's auto-correct's common

questions beginning with 'is b.' Okay, let's
start from the bottom "is Bearshare safe?"

No, but neither are ice pick lobotomies, which
we don't use anymore either. "Is Bob Harper

gay?" By the way, Bob Harper is a guy on The
Biggest Loser.

Let me answer your question with question,
Google. If we spend as much time thinking

about quantum physics as we do thinking about
whether celebrities are gay, do you think
we'd have a unified theory yet? I do!

"Is Bam Margera still married?" Yes, technically
although he and his wife live in different

cities. "Is Beyonce pregnant 2010?" No. "Is
Brett Favre married?" Yes. "Is Beezid a scam?"

No, it's just a rip-off. "Is Beyonce pregnant?"
Still no. "Is Bronchitis contagious?" Yes.

"Is bleach over?" No and lastly "is black
a color?"

Finally an interesting question! The answer
is yes and no. Functionally, it's a color.

If we mix all the primary colors together
we get something that very much resembles

black. But on the other hand, technically,
blackness is the absence of light, which is
a chromatic.

Then, Hank, I kept typing 'is b' until eventually
I typed 'is benj' and after the question of

whether Natalie Portman's fiance is Jewish
you come to "is Benjamin Button real?"

Hold on Hank, I have to make a quick journey
over to my desk. Ah headdesk!

Then we have "is Benjamin Franklin a president?"
A question with its present tense and indefinite

article implies either that we have more than
one president of the United States or that

Benjamin Franklin may be a member of the Presidents
of the United States of America. Sadly, neither

is the case. Benjamin Franklin was never the
president of the United States and he certainly

isn't now. In fact, it is my sad duty to inform
the googlers of the world that Benjamin Franklin,

American hero, patriot, non-president, has
died. Yes, Hank, the good always leave us

too soon. And Benjamin Franklin was a mere
84 years old when he died 221 years ago.

So anyway, Hank, I kept playing around and
then eventually I googled 'is bieb?' "Is Bieber

gay, german for basketball, in jail, bi, a
girl, really 51, dead, or going to North Korea?"

Also, "is bieberfever.com free?" Hank, you'll
be surprised to learn that the answer to all
these questions is either no or ahhhh.

So Hank, welcome to 2011, a year when Google
believed we wanted to know whether a popstar

was a deceased, imprisoned, fifty-one-year-old,
gay, bisexual, female, german basketball on

its way to North Korea. Hank, I think it's
safe to say that we did not imagine that world
on January 1st, 2007.

Nerdfighters, thanks for sticking with us
all this time we're gonna continue Monday-Wednesday-Friday

videos in 2011 but we have heard you that
you want more question videos, more Thoughts

from Places, and more info-tational videos.
And we are here to grant your wishes as long
as your wishes aren't weird.

To that end, I will be doing a question Tuesday
video this Friday so please leave questions

in the comments. I will answer as many of
them as I can in four minutes. Hank, DFTBA,

I will see you on Friday. Wednesday, right.
What you think my mental calendar suddenly's
going to improve after four years?
Oh, and by the way still nothing.

title: Is bronchitis contagious? Is black a color?

comments.text:
Regarding if black is a color:
It depends on if you're talking about light or pigment.

In the case of pigment (paints, physical materials, etc.), the answer is 
yes. When John mentions mixing primary colors together, he's talking about 
pigment.

In the case of light, however, what we perceive as black is not a color, 
it's the absence of light. It's simply not on the visible spectrum of 
light, which is what I'm using as the definition of a color in this 
context.﻿
comments.author: Lyricon

comments.text:
In art black is a shade. If you add it to a color it becomes darker. So is 
white, but it makes a color lighter.﻿

comments.author: sean doherty

comments.text:
Pretty darn sure that if you mix all colours together you get white, not 
black. Colour is determined by the energy spectrum of the light it 
reflects. All colours combined would reflect all colours, and thus be white 
light. ﻿
comments.author: rutger5000

comments.text:
+Jim Bowen I get what you're saying, but I think if that was true, mixing 
colours wouldn't work. Red paint + yellow paint still gives you orange 
paint ( if I remember kinder garden correctly). And red light + yellow 
light does give you orange light. 
You said that blue and black paint will give you black paint ( within your 
explination that makes sense). But blue and red paint give you purple paint.
I think you can simply add up the reflectance spectra of paints. So blue 
paint has a reflectance peak around blue light, likewise red paint has it 
around red light. I suppose the total reflectance of the mixed paints would 
remain identical, ( because you probably should also add up the absorbance 
spectra.)
comments.author: rutger5000

comments.text:
Not to be a pedant, but it depends on what you mean by "mixing all the 
colours together." If you're talking about paints or dyes, then mixing them 
together gives you black. Paints absorb every colour expect the one you 
see. So blue paint absorbs every colour except blue. The blue is reflected. 
If you add red paint to it, the red paint will absorb the blue light, which 
the blue paint will absorb the red, making it black.

If you're talking about light, mixing all the different colours gives you 
white light.

comments.text:
"Is bronchitis contagious?" "Yes."

Umm... I'm not sure I completely agree with this. Bronchitis is an 
inflammation of the bronchial tubes. Sure, there are viruses and bacteria 
that can *cause* bronchitis, and those are most likely contagious, but then 
again, speaking from personal experience... bleach can cause bronchitis 
too, if you're sensitive to bleach. I kind of doubt that the kind of 
bronchitis I usually get if I've been around bleach too long is contagious.﻿

comments.text: I have bronchitis and it is not contagious

My doctor says the underlying virus (if it's from a virus) is contagious, 
but that bronchitis itself is (and that therefore, I have no excuse to take 
time off of work, lol).

comments.text:
here's an interesting thought

if space was not full of the cosmic micro-wave backround, would it still be 
black?

you see, we assume black is the absence of light, but maybe black is just 
the color of heat (or any wavelenght beyond red) , since everywhere we look 
there is some infrared radiation, if you remove all visible light, you are 
left with the color of infrared, wich to us is black

a better question would be "what would a perfect vacuum look like?" a 
vacuum without any radiation at all, not even heat.﻿
comments.author: sidewaysfcs0718

comments.text:
Visible light, ultraviolet light, radio waves, gamma waves, and the other 
kinds of radiation that I forget are all technically the same thing. They 
are all the same energy, just moving in increasingly smaller waves. If you 
were to somehow lengthen the wavelength of gamma radiation, you would 
eventually turn it into visible light. Not that we are currently aware of 
any way to actually do that, mind you.

Our eyes are only "wired" to receive a wavelength of radiation from the 
color we call blue to the color we call red. Anything beyond that 
wavelength is too fast/small for us to see. One could argue that our eyes 
evolved to see this specific wavelength since this is the most common form 
of radiation on our planet. The early organisms that were born with birth 
defects that interpreted what we call visible light into a stimulus that 
gave them a general idea of how the world looked around them had a 
competitive edge over other organisms and thus were more likely to survive 
and pass on their genes.

If, for some idiotic reason, there were a planet with an abundance of gamma 
radiation, it would be reasonable to imagine that at some point, the 
organisms on that planet (assuming they were somehow resistant to the 
radiation) would evolve ocular nerves that used a wavelength including 
gamma radiation to visually sense their surroundings. Of course, their 
ocular nerves would probably fail to be stimulated by visible light.

Since our ocular nerves were developed at such an early stage that pretty 
much all animals share the common ancestor, we all have eyes that work 
essentially the same. The only major variation is that a lot of animals 
don't have cones in their eyes, only rods. This means that they cannot see 
color, only black and white.

But, if we were to imagine life evolving on another planet, it would, of 
course, lack our common ancestry. Thus, their ocular nerves, should they 
evolve any, would not even necessarily interpret the stimulus of visible 
light to be the same colors that we see. It might not even interpret the 
stimuli into anything that we humans would call the sensation of "sight" at 
all.

Which brings me back to the original point of discussion. Is gamma 
radiation or ultraviolet light or whatever black? Yes and no. The concept 
of color is an entirely human one. At BEST, it is an Earth concept. It is a 
result of our specific line of evolution. If someone's eyes were to be 
tweaked slightly, then the entire color spectrum would move in such a 
manner that Ultraviolet light would be the new red, and the wavelength that 
used to be blue would no longer be visible. Gamma radiation appears 
invisible (and thus black in the absence of visible light) to us because 
our eyes cannot sense it. That doesn't mean it is insensible and, 
therefore, necessarily black in all circumstances. It just means that is 
how humans see (or more accurately; don't see) it.

And, to answer the question of what a perfect vacuum would look like, it 
wouldn't look like anything. No ocular nerves would be able to pick up 
anything. Thus, from a human perspective, it would appear black, the 
absence of stimulus. Even a creature with differently evolved ocular nerves 
would be unable to receive any stimulus. Thus, it would still appear as 
their equivalent of the lack of stimulus.

And there you have it, a discussion on color from a non-humancentric point 
of view.
comments.author: TheDisarminghinkle

comments.text:
I would consider black to be the absence of visible light because by 
definition, visible light is light we can see. Infrared, ultraviolet, 
gamma, etc. radiation is not visible to us because it does not trigger rods 
or cones in our eyes, so yes, it appears black to us (if there is no 
visible light being emitted or reflected), but it is not black. The colors 
we see are combinations of different signals from rods and cones in our 
eyes, and so, if infrared radiation has no effect on our rods or cones, it 
does not matter if it is there or not, it still does not appear as anything 
to us; we would only see whatever visible light is emitted/reflected. Black 
is our name for what we see when we cannot see anything. Therefore, a 
perfect vacuum without any radiation, because it has no visible light, 
would be black.

comments.text:
You will understand that aggravating event when your close friend (who’s 
been a loser permanently) gets an incredible woman to fall for him in 2 
weeks?! Yep, that basically materialized. I am aware I should be pleased

comments.author: The Notorious B.R.Y.A.N.

comments.text: Please consult an art teacher or some shit.
comments.author: JoshLikeCrazy

comments.text:
Just to brake up that fight: I know you are talking about physical colours, 
but you are still wrong. You can draw with white on top of all colours, 
because there is such thing as white paint. If the nature of the paint 
allows it, you can colour something white. So it is not the absence of 
colour anymore but still white.
comments.author: Slinja

comments.text:
Please just google it. Please. It's ok to be wrong sometimes. white light 
n. Light that is a mixture of wavelengths of various colors and is 
perceived as colorless, as sunlight. If you coloured over the top of a pure 
white piece of paper (ignoring effects of the various chemicals in all 
these colours and the fact that 'white' paper is actually slightly blue) 
with all the wavelengths of the visible spectrum - i.e. all the colours 
bounced into your eye- you would see white.
comments.author: Shmifflepuff

comments.text:
Do you? Why is paper white? Because it is the absence of color. Why can 
every color color on top of white? Because it is the absence of color.
comments.author: JoshLikeCrazy

comments.text: ... Do you understand what colour is?
comments.author: Shmifflepuff

comments.text: I'm talking about COLOR, NOT LIGHT
comments.author: JoshLikeCrazy

comments.text:
Right, well the thing is that it isn't. Just google it quickly. White is 
the combination of all wavelengths of the visible spectrum.
comments.author: Shmifflepuff

comments.text: I said black is the absence of light, white IS the absence of colors
comments.author: JoshLikeCrazy

comments.text:
OK, well then I guess you just got it wrong :P White is the presence of all 
colours- all wavelengths of the visible spectrum- and black is the absence 
of light.
comments.author: Shmifflepuff

comments.text: I did not get the first two mixed up.
comments.author: JoshLikeCrazy

comments.text:
I think you got the first two mixed up and I assume by light you actually 
mean light of the visual part of the spectrum (which is a tiny fraction).
comments.author: Shmifflepuff

comments.text: Is Hank Green ... awesome. Now the first thing that shows up:)
